title: ANZ bank forced to pay back customers more than $1billion in wrongful fees
text:
ANZ has been forced to pay back its customers more than $1billion in fees and charges.

Australia's third largest bank was slammed by the banking royal commission in February, with former High Court judge Kenneth Hayne taking issue with ANZ's 'prolonged processes for identifying and then compensating customers'.

More than eight months after those findings were delivered, ANZ has announced it would be spending more than $1.1billion over two financial years paying back wrongful fees and charges to customers.

This included $682million for financial year 2019 following another $422million set aside in fiscal 2018.

Shortly before making the announcement, ANZ requested a trading halt on the New Zealand Exchange.

ANZ chief financial officer Michelle Jablko acknowledged that compensating customers would affect the shareholders.

'We recognise the impact this has on both customers and shareholders,' she said.

In the second half of the 2019 financial year, ANZ announced it would be putting $559million towards 'customer remediation'.

This figure included $405million after tax to remedy errors with fees and interest calculations and another $154million foregone from discontinuing bad practices.

'These include historical matters recently identified during the period, as well as refinements to estimates of existing customer compensation programs and associated costs,' ANZ said.

Ms Jablko said ANZ had 500 specialists ' working hard to get any money owed back to customers as quickly as possible'.

'We are well progressed in fixing issues,' she said.

In his final royal commission report, Justice Hayne criticised ANZ for first identifying problems in 2003 where customers would needed to be compensated for being charged wrongful fees adding 'too many' problems had yet to be rectified in March 2018.

'Banks must do more to prevent these errors,' he said.
description: Australia's third biggest bank has confirmed it would be spending $1.1billion over two financial years compensating customers for wrongful fees and charges.
authors: Stephen Johnson For Daily Mail Australia
